quizzes.question: Which is a correct rule for naming a variable?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Variable Naming Rules[/h1]

Use the following rules when naming variables:
- All variable names must begin with a letter of the alphabet or an underscore( _ ). 
- After the initial letter, variable names can contain additional letters, as well as numbers. Blank spaces or special characters are not allowed in variable names.
[note]There are two known naming conventions: 
[b]Pascal case[/b]: The first letter in the identifier and the first letter of each subsequent concatenated word are capitalized. For example: [b]BackColor[/b]
[b]Camel case: [/b]The first letter of an identifier is lowercase and the first letter of each subsequent concatenated word is capitalized. For example: [b]backColor[/b][/note]

quizzes.question: Which of the following are legal variable names in C++?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Case-Sensitivity[/h1]

C++ is [b]case-sensitive[/b], which means that an identifier written in uppercase is not equivalent to another one with the same name in lowercase. 
For example, [i]myvariable[/i] is not the same as [i]MYVARIABLE[/i] and not the same as [i]MyVariable[/i]. 
These are three [b]different [/b]variables. 
[note]Choose variable names that suggest the usage, for example: firstName, lastName.[/note]

[h1]Variable Naming Rules[/h1]

C++ keyword (reserved word) cannot be used as variable names.
For example, [b]int[/b], [b]float[/b], [b]double[/b], [b]cout [/b]cannot be used as a variable name. 
[note]There is no real limit on the length of the variable name (depends on the environment), but try to keep your variable names [b]practical [/b]and [b]meaningful[/b].[/note]
